dk.statsbiblioteket.util.reader
Class CharArrayReplacer

java.lang.Object
  java.io.Reader
      java.io.FilterReader
          dk.statsbiblioteket.util.reader.ReplaceReader
              dk.statsbiblioteket.util.reader.CharArrayReplacer
All Implemented Interfaces:
TextTransformer, java.io.Closeable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Readable
@QAInfo(level=NORMAL,
        state=IN_DEVELOPMENT,
        author="te")
public class CharArrayReplacer
extends ReplaceReader

A highly speed-optimized single char to char array replacer. The implementation maintains an array of all possible char values (65536) mapped to their replacements, thereby making lookup of a single char O(1).

This implementation is semi-thread safe. All methods except setSource(java.io.Reader) and setSource(CircularCharBuffer) can be called safely from different threads.

See Also:
CharReplacer}.

Constructor Detail

CharArrayReplacer

public CharArrayReplacer(java.io.Reader in,
                         java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> rules)
Create a new replacer based on a map with rules, consisting of target chars and replacement chars.

If a rule contains a target or a replacement that isn't exactly 1 char long, an exception is thrown.

Parameters:
in - the character stream in which to replace substrings
rules - the rules used for replacing chars.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if one or more of the reules are illegal for this TextTransformer.

CharArrayReplacer

public CharArrayReplacer(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> rules)
Create a new replacer with an empty input stream set based on a map of target chars and replacement chars.

You should set the input character stream of the new reader by calling setSource(java.io.Reader).

If a rule contains a target or a replacement that isn't exactly 1 char long, an exception is thrown.

Parameters:
rules - the rules used for replacing chars.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if one or more of the reules are illegal for this TextTransformer.
Method Detail

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()
A clone of the CharReplacer will share the rules of the replacer, but will otherwise be independent. A clone will not have a source defined. Creating a clone is very cheap with regard to memory and processing time.

Specified by:
clone in class ReplaceReader
Returns:
a clone of this ReplaceReader.

Transforms a single char to an array of chars.

Parameters:
c - the char to transform.
Returns:
the output chars, possibly of length 0.

transformToChars

public char[] transformToChars(char[] chars)
Replaces the characters in the given array.

This implementation uses ThreadLocal in order to allow for concurrent usage. The downside is degraded performance if it is called with a new thread every time. Fortunately this is not a very common scenario.

Parameters:
chars - the characters to replace.
Returns:
the result of the replacing.

transformToCharsAllowInplace

public char[] transformToCharsAllowInplace(char[] chars)
Description copied from interface: TextTransformer
Transforms an array of chars to an array of chars.

If the transformation results in exactly the same number of chars as the input, it is allowed for the implementation to re-use the input array.

Parameters:
chars - the chars to transform.
Returns:
the output chars, possibly of length 0.

read

public int read()
         throws java.io.IOException
Reads the next processed char. Note that this is synchronized and that threads competing for access share the output stream with read(CircularCharBuffer, int) and read(char[], int, int).

Specified by:
read in interface TextTransformer
Overrides:
read in class java.io.FilterReader
Returns:
the next char or -1 if there are no more chars available.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occured.

read

public int read(CircularCharBuffer cbuf,
                int length)
         throws java.io.IOException
Fills transformed chars in the buffer. Note that this is synchronized and that threads competing for access share the output stream with read() and read(char[], int, int).

Parameters:
cbuf - the buffer to assign shars to.
length - the maximum number of chars to put in the buffer.
Returns:
the number of chars filled or -1 if there are no more chars.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occured.
